do not know whether the traffic will be clear or congested.  

We do not know if our flight will be delayed or canceled.  

We do not know if we’ll slip on a slick road tomorrow.  

We do not know if we will break our wrist.  

In the workplace, we do not know if a supplier will be late.  

We do not know if a colleague will drop the ball.  

We do not know if a client will change directions at the last minute.  

The only thing we can expect is the unexpected.  

We can either wait for the moment and react to it.  

Or we can prepare.  

We can create a buffer.  

A “buffer” prevents two things from coming into contact.  

It stops them from harming each other.  

A “buffer zone” is an area of land.  

It creates extra space between a protected area and potential threats.  

I once tried to explain buffers to my children.  

We were in the car together.  

I used a game to explain the idea.  

Imagine we had to get to our destination three miles away.  

We had to do this without stopping.  

The children saw the challenge immediately.  

We couldn’t predict what would happen in front of us.  

We didn’t know how long the light would stay green.  

We didn’t know if the car in front would swerve or brake.  

To avoid crashing, we needed extra space.  

This space acted as a buffer.  

It gave us time to respond to unexpected moves.  

It helped us avoid violent stops and starts.  

We can reduce friction in our work by creating a buffer.  

During the car game, my children noticed something.  

When I got distracted, I forgot the buffer zone.  

I got too close to the car in front.  

Then I had to swerve or slam on the brakes.  

We can forget to respect and maintain buffers in our lives.  

We get busy and distracted.  

Before we know it, the project is due.  

The day of the big presentation has arrived.  

We are forced to swerve or slam on the brakes at the last minute.  

Gases expand to fill the space they are in.  

Similarly, we’ve all experienced this in our lives.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Creating buffers in our lives helps us manage the unexpected and reduces friction in executing essential tasks.
